facts.text: Munnalal was the cashier of the Municipal Board of Hardwar since 1932 and in charge of cash with duty to deposit funds exceeding Rs. 4,000/- in treasury or Imperial Bank at Roorkee.
Audit on May 24, 1949 found Rs. 52,144/- received by Board from April 20 to May 23, 1949 not deposited.
Appellant admitted spending some money on daughter's marriage, some in his shop, Rs. 10,000-11,000/- to Executive Officer, remainder at home.
Appellant suspended, matter to police; case under s.409 IPC against appellant, brother (Assistant Cashier) and Executive Officer.
IPC case withdrawn as covered by s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act; sanction obtained; four prosecutions launched against appellant and brother.
Special Judge ordered three separate trials of appellant alone for certain moneys plus four joint trials, totaling seven trials.
These appeals concern three trials: Appeal 102 - Rs. 1623/4/- (Apr 14-May 23,1949); Appeal 103 - Rs. 9611-9-6 (Apr 20-May 24,1949); Appeal 104 - Rs. 43087/3 (Apr 20-May 24,1949), not deposited.

Appellant admitted receipt of moneys (except few items found received) and duty to deposit above Rs.4,000/-; inconsistent defence: first deposits, alternatively practice of advances to Executive Officer and employees via slips, used as banker, moneys not deposited due to constant advances.
Special Judge held moneys received (except two items), appellant dishonestly misappropriated or converted or allowed others to do so under s.5(2) r/w s.5(1)(c) PC Act.
Sentences by Special Judge: 5 years RI concurrent for appeals 102/103; 5 years RI + Rs.42,000 fine for 104.
High Court upheld convictions, reduced sentences to 2 years RI concurrent, set aside fine due to practice of advances and 11-year delay.
Original investigation by Sub-Inspector; later DSP authorized but only reviewed papers, no fresh investigation.
Practice of advances to officers including Executive Officer proved; officers knew moneys not deposited.
Appellant in jail over 10 months; cases prolonged 11 years since 1949.

legal_issues.text: Whether investigation irregular under s.5A PC Act as done by Sub-Inspector, later DSP only reviewed papers.
Whether proper sanction for split-up cases (three new from four original) and for s.5(1)(c) r/w s.5(2) PC Act.
Whether sentence excessive given practice of advances to superiors, appellant more sinned against, time served sufficient.

petitioner_arguments.text: Investigation irregular, not in accordance with s.5A PC Act as real investigation by unauthorized Sub-Inspector.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.5A Prevention of Corruption Act; H.N. Rishbud v. State of Delhi

petitioner_arguments.text: No proper sanction for three split-up cases from original four; sanction not for s.5(1)(c).

Convictions unjustified; appellant obliged superiors including Executive Officer in established practice of advances; not converted to own use; already served 10+ months, 11-year delay sufficient punishment.

respondent_arguments.text: Did not press for confirmation of High Court's reduced sentence.

court_reasoning.text: Even if s.5A violated, no miscarriage of justice as appellant admitted substance, no prejudice shown; Rishbud applies, not Mubarak Ali as no early objection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Illegality in investigation does not vitiate trial unless miscarriage of justice.

court_reasoning.text: Sanction covered split cases as amounts from original sanctioned cases; sanction allegations imply s.5(1)(c) (misappropriation/embezzlement).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sanction sufficient for jurisdiction under s.5(1)(c) r/w s.5(2).

court_reasoning.text: Convictions justified as duty to follow rules not done; but scandalous practice by superiors including EO; appellant obliged them; sentence undergone meets ends of justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant more sinned against than sinning.

holdings.text: Irregularity in investigation under s.5A does not vitiate trial without miscarriage of justice.
Sanction valid for split cases and s.5(1)(c) r/w s.5(2) PC Act.
Convictions upheld but sentence reduced to period already undergone.

precedents_cited.case_name: H.N. Rishbud v. State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: s.5A mandatory but violation does not vitiate trial unless miscarriage of justice.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Mubarak Ali
precedents_cited.relevance: Objection at early stage before trial led to stay for proper investigation; inapplicable here as no early objection.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of criminal misconduct by public servant; investigation and sanction requirements; applied to convict appellant.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Initial case under criminal breach of trust; withdrawn as covered by PC Act.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for Special Judge to split trials.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's convictions under s.5(2) r/w s.5(1)(c) PC Act but reduced sentences to period already undergone by appellant (over 10 months), considering practice of advances by superiors and 11-year delay.

key_quotes.text: "the appellant was more sinned against than sinning"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Captures court's sympathy for appellant due to superiors' role in misappropriation.

key_quotes.text: "if cognizance is in fact taken on a police report despite breach of a mandatory provision relating to investigation, the results which follow cannot be set aside unless the illegality in the investigation has brought about a miscarriage of justice."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding from Rishbud on effect of s.5A violation.

key_quotes.text: "the evidence discloses a scandalous state of affairs which was allowed to go on and even the highest officer of the Board, namely, the Executive Officer, was cognizant of this state of affairs and was himself a party to it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
